sen.j: 所務（しょむ）とは、所領の管理（検断及び年貢・租税徴収）を行うこと。
sen.e: Shomu meant management of territory (trial and collection of nengu (main land tax levied on the peasants based on the estimated productivity of land) and sozei (single land tax or combined land tax).)

sen.j: また、それに伴う得分（所務職（しょむしき））のことを指す。
sen.e: It also meant the income (shomu shiki) from the management.

sen.cmt: 括弧の位置を移動しました。

sen.j: 元来は務めるところという字義どおり仕事・職務を意味しており、『続日本紀』に事例を見出せるが、平安時代の荘園公領制の展開に伴い、荘園や公領の管理とこれに付随する権利・義務を表すようになった。
sen.e: It originally meant job and duty as the Chinese character 所務 literally means (where a person works), an example of which was shown in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued); and in the Heian period, as shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates) developed, it came to mean the management of the private estates and the public lands and right and obligation involved in that.

sen.j: これに伴う得分は職の体系の中で所務職として確立され、また所務を預所が務める事が多かった事から、預所職（あずかりどころしき）とも称した。
sen.e: The income from the management and the right and obligation involved therein was established as shomu shiki in the structure of offices, and as azukaridokoro (a deputy of "Shoen" manor lord) often did shomu, it was also called azukaridokoro shiki (the right that azukaridokoro (a deputy of Shoen manor lord) had.)
